articles.headline: Volcker Rule on Bank Risk Approaches Its Final Edits
articles.snippet: Federal regulators have reached a tentative agreement to vote next week on the new rule, overcoming internal squabbling and an onslaught of Wall Street lobbying.
articles.abstract: Federal regulators have reached a tentative agreement to vote next week on the new rule, overcoming internal squabbling and an onslaught of Wall Street lobbying.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:56 p.m. | Federal regulators have reached a tentative agreement to complete a rule aimed at Wall Street risk-taking, federal officials said on Tuesday, overcoming internal squabbling and an onslaught of Wall Street lobbying that stymied them for years.

articles.headline: Editor Describes Pressure After Leaks by Snowden
articles.snippet: Testimony to Parliament from the top editor of The Guardian illustrated the aggressive investigative and spying tactics increasingly faced by news organizations.
articles.abstract: Testimony to Parliament from the top editor of The Guardian illustrated the aggressive investigative and spying tactics increasingly faced by news organizations.
articles.lead_paragraph: The top editor of the British newspaper The Guardian told Parliament on Tuesday that since it obtained documents on government surveillance from a former National Security Agency contractor, Edward J. Snowden, it has met with government agencies in Britain and the United States more than 100 times and has been subjected to measures “designed to intimidate.”

articles.headline: Americanized Labor Policy Is Spreading in Europe
articles.snippet: Desperate to restore competitiveness, European nations are dismantling workplace protections that once supported labor and helped minimize income inequality.
articles.abstract: Desperate to restore competitiveness, European nations are dismantling workplace protections that once supported labor and helped minimize income inequality.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2008, 1.9 million Portuguese workers in the private sector were covered by collective bargaining agreements. Last year, the number was down to 300,000.

articles.headline: An Unexpected Apology Stokes the Embers of a Feud
articles.snippet: Sean Egan and Richard B. Handler clashed two years ago over a downgrade in credit ratings. In recent weeks, reconciliation appeared to be no closer.
articles.abstract: Sean Egan and Richard B. Handler clashed two years ago over a downgrade in credit ratings. In recent weeks, reconciliation appeared to be no closer.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it comes to Wall Street grudge matches, this one is sure to rank right up there.

articles.headline: Rare Cancer Treatments, Cleared by F.D.A. but Not Subject to Scrutiny
articles.snippet: The F.D.A. allows the sale of some devices to treat small groups of patients without requiring proof that the devices work, or any rigorous study of the medical results.
articles.abstract: The F.D.A. allows the sale of some devices to treat small groups of patients without requiring proof that the devices work, or any rigorous study of the medical results.
articles.lead_paragraph: When federal regulators permitted the sale of an unproved device that uses intense heat to combat cancer, they did so for a compelling reason, to give hope to some women desperately ill with cervical cancer.

articles.headline: Jihadist Groups Gain in Turmoil Across Middle East
articles.snippet: Al Qaeda’s leader, Ayman al-Zawahri, has indicated that he views Syria as a promising staging ground, and officials are concerned that a base there could present a rising threat to Israel and Europe.
articles.abstract: Al Qaeda’s leader, Ayman al-Zawahri, has indicated that he views Syria as a promising staging ground, and officials are concerned that a base there could present a rising threat to Israel and Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Intensifying sectarian and clan violence has presented new opportunities for jihadist groups across the Middle East and raised concerns among American intelligence and counterterrorism officials that militants aligned with Al Qaeda could establish a base in Syria capable of threatening Israel and Europe.
articles.byline: By Robert F. Worth and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Hands-On Bavarian Count Presides Over a Pencil-Making Empire
articles.snippet: At a picturesque century-old factory, Count Anton-Wolfgang von Faber-Castell is the eighth in a long line carrying on the family name in the pencil business.
articles.abstract: At a picturesque century-old factory, Count Anton-Wolfgang von Faber-Castell is the eighth in a long line carrying on the family name in the pencil business.
articles.lead_paragraph: STEIN, Germany — Count Anton-Wolfgang von Faber-Castell has been known to hurl wooden pencils from the tower of his castle to the stone courtyard below.

articles.headline: Google Puts Money on Robots, Using the Man Behind Android
articles.snippet: Led by Andy Rubin, who built the Android software, Google has acquired seven companies with hopes to automate manufacturing and even rival Amazon in retail delivery.
articles.abstract: Led by Andy Rubin, who built the Android software, Google has acquired seven companies with hopes to automate manufacturing and even rival Amazon in retail delivery.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — In an out-of-the-way Google office, two life-size humanoid robots hang suspended in a corner.

articles.headline: Europe Sets Big Fines in Settling Libor Case
articles.snippet: Joining a chorus of regulators worldwide, European Union antitrust officials fined a group of global financial institutions – including for the first time two American banks.
articles.abstract: Joining a chorus of regulators worldwide, European Union antitrust officials fined a group of global financial institutions – including for the first time two American banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Demonstrating a new resolve to punish bank misconduct, the European Union fined a group of global financial institutions a combined 1.7 billion euros ($2.3 billion) on Wednesday to settle charges that they colluded to fix benchmark interest rates.
articles.byline: By Chad Bray and Jack Ewing
